item.title: Advanced Stats and Predicting NBA Wins
item.dc:creator: dlm1223@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
The most important quality of a player metric in basketball should be its ability to predict team wins. I'm late on board the RAPM train but I'm just learning about it and am interested in seeing how useful these advanced stats are in predicting next season wins. I basically did a variation of a forum post from Neil Paine where he applied lagged metrics to a player's current season's minutes to see the correlation with team wins. He found previous season-RAPM was much more correlated to a team's wins than other stats like PER or Win Shares. If you're reading this and don't know about RAPM/RPM/BPM, there's an explanation at the bottom.** I wanted to do something similar to Neil Paine but instead create a predictive model for wins. To do this, what I did was take the opening day roster from RealGM and multiply each player's last metric value by their LastMinutes then sum the values for the team. Rookies get the mean value for a rookie which is around 13 minutes per game, and they get the mean metric values for a rookie. Below you can see how this looks for Denver in 2017. And then after summing: These are the correlations to PCT for everything for 2006-2012.
  • Win.Total is the vegas pre-season team win total converted to a percentage.
  • LastPCT is the team's last win-percent and LastDIFF is the team's last scoring differential.
  • RPM_adj is an estimate of RPM since I was unable to get RPM data pre-2014. It can be estimated reasonably using a weighted sum of BPM and RAPM.
  • PREDPCT is just an initial attempt at a linear model to predict PCT using a few of the metrics in addition to Win.Total. Obviously, this is all in-sample at the moment.
As you can see, the advanced RPM/RAPM/BPM stats are most accurate so clearly there is something to them. I use 2006-2012 so I will be able to try out different models and look at the 2013-17 test set as little as possible. It is a good sign that accuracy can be achieved quickly and hopefully PREDPCT can be improved with some experimentation. ________________________________________ *** I don't know why they gave every metric the same name... Anyway, RAPM is derived using play-by-play data and stands for regularized-adjusted-plus-minus. It uses lineups data in the PBP data to try to improve upon regular plus-minus by removing the effect of teammates. It does this by solving a system of equations using all the lineups and plus-minuses. It then uses regularization in attempt to decrease noise and increase predictive accuracy of the metric. BPM is different and comes from a model that uses box score data to estimate a player's RAPM. BPM is more comparable to something like PER because it is a metric that comes from a box score, although in BPM's case it has weights that are more empirically decided; in this case they are decided to optimize accuracy to RAPM. BPM also has the nice property of being more stable and more correlated year to year compared to RAPM which is very unstable year to year. Lastly, RPM is similar to RAPM, but weights the RAPM values using BPM as a prior. Doing this helps reduce small-sample size noise of RAPM.

item.title: March Madness Algorithm
item.dc:creator: dlm1223@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
Background March Madness Algorithms are not that popular in January but I feel like posting my system that I used last year, so here it is. Overall, a system should balance point maximization with being contrarian. For example, if Kentucky is estimated to have a 20% chance to win it all and is being picked by 40% of people and Virginia has a 15% chance and is being picked at a 5% rate, then it is obvious you should go with Virginia since they are being undervalued. However, it is unclear how this applies in earlier rounds. Having a methodology to balance expected value and pick-percentage in a mathematical way and for an entire bracket is something I have not seen a lot. Step 1: Projections and Simulation The first step is to estimate win-probabilities for each matchup. I got 2017 files from Kaggle last year which made it easy to get this done because they had the seeds and regions all organized. Once win-probabilities are estimated for each possible matchup, you can simulate the tournament many times. [caption id="attachment_226" align="alignnone" width="381"] Probability of Reaching Each Round- 2017 Tournament , aggregated from 500 simulations[/caption] Step 2: Apply Scoring System To Each Simulation The next step is to apply your pools scoring system to each simulation to get how many points a pick would yield in that simulation. The pool I enter gives you double points if the team won in an upset, and so doing it this way allows you to account for this. For example, having a 2-seed Virginia as champion might yield 0 points, 40 points, or 80 points, depending on if they won the championship in that simulation and whether they had beaten a 1-seed to win it in that simulation. Now I have a set of simulations with corresponding pick payouts for each simulation. Step 3: Generate Pool of Brackets ESPN publishes what percentage of people are putting each team into each round and has these available pre-tournament. Using these pick-percentages, you can create a large random set of brackets that resemble the brackets picked by the field. It is hopefully a good estimate but obviously things like a pools scoring system or regional bias might affect a given pool. [caption id="attachment_227" align="alignnone" width="591"] ESPN Pick Percentages[/caption] Step 4: Calculate Pool Results for Each Simulation If we had done 2000 tournament simulations and had 1000 brackets generated in the pool of brackets, then you have 2000 different final pool-standings. For example, Bracket 1 might have finishes of 3rd, 642nd, 19th, 1st, etc. This allows you to see which brackets can finish towards the top. [caption id="attachment_224" align="alignnone" width="894"] Top Projected Brackets, sorted by P(97th Percentile)[/caption] Step 5: Multiple Entry and Pool-Size Strategy Finally, you can set up an optimization based on number of brackets and pool size. For example, choose the 3 brackets that together maximize my chances of having at least one 97th-percentile finish. Or pick the 1 bracket that maximizes your chance of a 90thpercentile finish. Below are some plots based on my pool's scoring system. The software I am currently using (C-Plex Community Edition) has a limit on number of variables and so this is all with 500 brackets and 500 simulations. [caption id="attachment_219" align="alignnone" width="335"] Probability of a top finish is correlated to a bracket's projection[/caption] [caption id="attachment_228" align="alignnone" width="637"] Optimal solution, percentile=97th, numBrackets=3. Leads to greater chance of top finish rather than just taking the top brackets.[/caption]
[caption id="attachment_222" align="alignnone" width="443"] Optimally diversified brackets(blue), top 3 individual brackets (red), and histogram of groups of 3 randomly selected brackets. Estimated 31.4% chance of finishing in top3% with optimal diversification.[/caption] Summary In summary, the steps are 1. simulate the tournament from estimated win probabilities, 2. generate pool of brackets corresponding to ownership percentages, 3. take brackets from pool that give you best chance of beating the other brackets over the simulations. In theory I think the system should work well and the only parameters to adjust are the number of brackets and x-percentile finish. I didnt look into how this system has actually performed which is very important and so I need to organize the results data and hopefully can put together a backtest. Update: I also made an app for march madness so check it out.

item.title: Ranking NCAA Transfers (Part 1)
item.dc:creator: dlm1223@gmail.com
item.content:encoded: I'd like to rank NCAA basketball transfers. I think this could be really worthwhile because there are so many transfers at different levels of NCAA basketball. And the NCAA is considering allowing people to transfer without sitting out so it might become crazy. To do all of this analytically, I need to consider which stats are the most worthwhile to project. The first thing I look at is which stats are correlated with next-year stats. I got the data fromrealgmand it includes all D1 players from 2004-present. All of these stats are pace-adjusted and also scaled by minutes played. This does not apply to the advanced stats like WS, USG., or TS., since scaling those by minutes played doesn't make as much sense. Here you can see that things like BLK/MIN and FG3M/MIN carry over well for transfers. This is a useful chart, but if I'm going to decide what stats I should project at the player level, I should consider which stats are most important at the team level. To do this, for each team I take the weighted average of each player's previous season stat, weighted by how many minutes they played in the current season for the team. For example, LastTOV._team=mean(LastTOV.*CurrentMPG*CurrentGP). I then see how well this weighted sum is correlated to the end of season Ken-Pom Rank. I am trying to capture how useful the last-season stats are. For comparison I show the Last-Year End of Season KPom Rank. As you can see, the advanced stats are somewhat useful, as they are better at estimating a players' total impact versus just using an individual stat. This chart is useful because I can now rule out using stats like ORtg and PER since compared to WS they are harder to project, and also less correlated to team's wins. Stats that I will look into are WS, BLK, and AST. Actually projecting the stats and using things like age and returning minutes should help improve the accuracy even more. The code for this is on github.

item.title: Ranking NCAA Transfers (Part 2) - Win Share Projections
item.dc:creator: dlm1223@gmail.com
item.content:encoded: In my last post I went through why Win Shares are a decent ranking method for transfers and for players. As a summary, it is because they are correlated to how many games a team will win, and they are also relatively predictable for people transferring. In this post I will display the first run of my transfer rankings. I am projecting players' next-season Win-Shares, using things like their previous seasons, their recruiting ranking, and more. RankAgg is their ESPN ranking, or their 247-composite ranking if they are not in the ESPN top 100, or it is 550 if they were not in the 247-top 350. The reasons for all of these decisions is to increase the accuracy of the projections. Below you can see projections for rookies/transfers eligible in this past season and next season, and transfers eligible in 2020. [googleapps domain="docs" dir="spreadsheets/d/e/2PACX-1vQicmMWHcfzkJmK3QCA_wrqtR-u4qpjLQnJGp8eavjPLNlj3NpM01tCzy_rZGlPjqFlNXnS4wkvP5pX/pubhtml" query="widget=true&headers=false" /] View the full spreadsheet here. I think Win-Shares are a decent measure and can compare players from a variety of different backgrounds. For these rankings, I am treating all players as if they are going to the same team. For example, a player going to play at a low-ranked team should really have more projected win-shares than a player going to play at Kansas. Using this will increase the accuracy, but will make the player projections less comparable, and so I just treat all players as if they are going to the same team. In a future post I will show how accurate the projections are and how correlated they are to a team's end-of-season rank. There are definitely improvements I can make and bugs I can fix, but I wanted to write up this first run and show what good players are still out there. If you're a coach at UVa, hit me up and I'll give you all the real secrets.

item.title: Ranking NCAA Transfers (Part 3) - Transfers are Underrated
item.dc:creator: dlm1223@gmail.com
item.content:encoded: In this post I'll talk about why getting a top transfer is just as good as getting a top recruit. Scroll to the bottom of the post if you want to see the current transfer projections. To project transfers, I've been using the statistic Win-shares. I picked it because it is relatively predictable year-to-year for transfers, and because it is correlated to how good a team will be. In this post I will talk about the projection accuracy of the projections. Even if you don't care about win-shares or the rankings, looking at their accuracy still provides useful insights. Below I plot the accuracy of my projections for 2004-2018, grouped by player type: COR is the correlation of the projections to the actuals, which is just a value from 0 to 1. MAE is the mean error of the projection to the actual values, so a lower value is better. The chart shows that players returning to their same team are most easily projected, and rookies and transfers have similar accuracy. Constricting it to the top 20 transfers/recruits shows similar results. The correlation and MAE for the top 20 recruits/transfers is not great, however, they are not great for both sets of players. You can also view this as a scatterplot.. What all of this shows is how if a recruit and transfer are similarly projected, there probably shouldn't be preference given to the top recruit. Projecting a guy coming out of Utah State is similarly as challenging as projecting a guy from High School. Especially if you can get a guy with >1 year of eligibility left, it definitely seems to me that getting a top transfer is just as goodas getting a top recruit who will likely leave. You can view the current projections below.   [googleapps domain="docs" dir="spreadsheets/d/e/2PACX-1vQicmMWHcfzkJmK3QCA_wrqtR-u4qpjLQnJGp8eavjPLNlj3NpM01tCzy_rZGlPjqFlNXnS4wkvP5pX/pubhtml" query="widget=true&headers=false" /]   Full Spreadsheet. Github Code

item.title: Optimization for Fantasy Football Snake Drafts
item.dc:creator: dlm1223@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
• Base Case
  • More Complex Case
    • Error Analysis
    • Simulation
    • Optimizing Parameters
    • Analyzing Bias
  • Conclusion

Base Case

Optimizing your strategy for a fantasy football draft is an interesting problem. Should you should go RB early? Wait on RB's? Should you do something productive with your free time instead of fantasy football? (probably). In this post I will go through my optimization methodology. To start, I have a dataframe of players and their projected points and their ADPs (Average draft positions). 
head(adp[, c("Player", "Pos", "ADP_est", "ADPSD_est", "ADP_Rank", "HALF", "STD", "PPR")], 25)

##                  Player Pos ADP_est ADPSD_est ADP_Rank     HALF      STD      PPR
## 120         Todd Gurley  RB    1.85      0.90        1 286.9787 278.7288 295.3511
## 119         Leveon Bell  RB    2.25      1.00        2 285.5994 276.2004 294.9930
## 118     Ezekiel Elliott  RB    3.40      1.35        3 245.7330 240.7392 250.8822
## 117       David Johnson  RB    3.90      1.10        4 237.7158 232.9482 242.4851
## 123       Antonio Brown  WR    5.10      1.40        5 244.1744 220.2120 268.1369
## 122        Alvin Kamara  RB    6.00      1.25        6 245.4832 235.7970 255.2076
## 82       Saquon Barkley  RB    6.80      1.80        7 221.9244 216.4002 227.4485
## 87      Deandre Hopkins  WR    8.80      1.90        8 217.1364 196.1761 238.0967
## 121         Kareem Hunt  RB    9.30      1.75        9 229.6042 222.5463 236.7176
## 78    Leonard Fournette  RB   10.00      1.80       10 213.3087 207.6375 219.0514
## 79        Melvin Gordon  RB   10.45      2.05       11 212.0997 205.3586 218.8665
## 89        Odell Beckham  WR   11.50      2.05       12 196.8351 178.9319 214.7382
## 76          Dalvin Cook  RB   12.90      2.00       13 204.0279 199.3044 208.7746
## 93          Julio Jones  WR   14.10      2.15       14 224.4879 202.2329 246.7428
## 85       Michael Thomas  WR   15.90      2.30       15 208.1782 188.1379 228.2185
## 81      Devonta Freeman  RB   17.55      2.50       16 202.7999 196.5961 209.0049
## 94        Davante Adams  WR   18.10      2.40       17 176.9410 161.1901 192.6918
## 95         Keenan Allen  WR   18.40      2.50       18 193.9841 176.8953 211.0729
## 80         Lesean Mccoy  RB   18.85      2.90       19 195.3838 189.0302 201.7331
## 83  Christian Mccaffrey  RB   20.15      3.10       20 213.4223 203.1830 223.5142
## 96             Aj Green  WR   20.55      2.25       21 185.0449 168.3994 201.6903
## 77      Jerick Mckinnon  RB   20.60      3.50       22 194.1646 187.8265 200.4310
## 26        Jordan Howard  RB   22.10      3.05       23 170.0072 166.0453 174.0318
## 86        Michael Evans  WR   23.55      2.75       24 182.9814 164.8576 201.1052
## 84    Robert Gronkowski  TE   23.70      3.65       25 176.8560 160.0528 193.6592
For league settings, I am using Yahoo's defaults[1]. I can then easily set up an optimization where I say to maximize the sum of the projected points of the 15 players taken, given the slot I am picking at, which for this example I will say is slot 4. In other words, I maximize projected points of my lineup, constraining it to take 15 players with ADP>=4, 14 players with ADP>=21, etc. The end result is a function which takes different parameters for the optimization and returns the optimal draft picks. 
getPicks(slot="Slot4", numRB=4, numWR = 6,numTE=1,numK=1,numQB=2, numDST=1,numFLEX = 0,shift=0,  out=c(), fix=c(), scoring='HALF')

##     Pos              Player ADP_est ADP_Rank     HALF Slot
## 122  RB        Alvin Kamara    6.00      6.0 245.4832    4
## 77   RB     Jerick Mckinnon   20.60     22.0 194.1646   21
## 88   WR         Tyreek Hill   29.65     29.0 184.3552   28
## 90   WR Juju Smith Schuster   42.35     45.0 179.3604   45
## 106  QB      Russell Wilson   57.10     57.5 291.4859   52
## 109  QB          Cam Newton   74.05     76.0 274.0508   69
## 32   TE      Delanie Walker   79.15     80.0 132.7886   76
## 61   WR         Cooper Kupp  100.70    100.0 149.4343   93
## 42   WR      Robby Anderson  104.65    107.0 145.7251  100
## 62   WR    Sterling Shepard  119.10    125.0 139.7021  117
## 387  RB     Devontae Booker  119.40    126.0 122.6159  124
## 40   WR    Rishard Matthews  142.75    146.0 133.4577  141
## 30   RB         James White  149.30    155.0 137.4044  148
## 315 DST                 Pit  163.35    186.0 122.0000  165
## 5     K     Harrison Butker      NA    500.0 145.3158  172
The parameters of getPicks() specify number of players at each position to take. I also added the "shift" parameter which can shift everyone's ADP by a given fraction i.e. shift=.1 would subtract 10% from everyone's ADP. I can also make adjustments like constraining to only select 1QB in the first 10 rounds, or any other number of custom constraints. 
getPicks(slot="Slot4", numRB=4, numWR = 6,numTE=1,numK=1,numQB=2, numDST=1,numFLEX = 0,shift=0,  out=c(), fix=c(), scoring='HALF', onePos=rep("QB", 10))

##     Pos              Player ADP_est ADP_Rank     HALF Slot
## 122  RB        Alvin Kamara    6.00      6.0 245.4832    4
## 77   RB     Jerick Mckinnon   20.60     22.0 194.1646   21
## 88   WR         Tyreek Hill   29.65     29.0 184.3552   28
## 90   WR Juju Smith Schuster   42.35     45.0 179.3604   45
## 106  QB      Russell Wilson   57.10     57.5 291.4859   52
## 15   RB         Tarik Cohen   75.80     78.0 132.4949   69
## 32   TE      Delanie Walker   79.15     80.0 132.7886   76
## 61   WR         Cooper Kupp  100.70    100.0 149.4343   93
## 42   WR      Robby Anderson  104.65    107.0 145.7251  100
## 39   WR     Kelvin Benjamin  112.70    117.0 137.0975  117
## 62   WR    Sterling Shepard  119.10    125.0 139.7021  124
## 107  QB     Alexander Smith  148.65    152.0 259.3228  141
## 30   RB         James White  149.30    155.0 137.4044  148
## 315 DST                 Pit  163.35    186.0 122.0000  165
## 5     K     Harrison Butker      NA    500.0 145.3158  172
Rotoviz already has an app which does a similar optimization. The results do seem to suggest certain things like how you should often take RB's early. Looking at the optimal first two picks for each draft slot, you can see how RB's are usually suggested for the early picks: 
sapply(paste0("Slot", 1:12), function(x) getPicks(slot=x, numRB=4, numWR = 6,numTE=1,numK=1,numQB=2, numDST=1,numFLEX = 0,shift=0,  out=c(), fix=c(), scoring='HALF')[1:2,],simplify = FALSE,USE.NAMES = TRUE)

## $Slot1
##     Pos            Player ADP_est ADP_Rank     HALF Slot
## 120  RB       Todd Gurley    1.85        1 286.9787    1
## 84   TE Robert Gronkowski   23.70       25 176.8560   24
## 
## $Slot2
##     Pos            Player ADP_est ADP_Rank     HALF Slot
## 119  RB       Leveon Bell    2.25        2 285.5994    2
## 84   TE Robert Gronkowski   23.70       25 176.8560   23
## 
## $Slot3
##     Pos          Player ADP_est ADP_Rank     HALF Slot
## 118  RB Ezekiel Elliott     3.4        3 245.7330    3
## 77   RB Jerick Mckinnon    20.6       22 194.1646   22
## 
## $Slot4
##     Pos          Player ADP_est ADP_Rank     HALF Slot
## 122  RB    Alvin Kamara     6.0        6 245.4832    4
## 77   RB Jerick Mckinnon    20.6       22 194.1646   21
## 
## $Slot5
##     Pos              Player ADP_est ADP_Rank     HALF Slot
## 122  RB        Alvin Kamara    6.00        6 245.4832    5
## 83   RB Christian Mccaffrey   20.15       20 213.4223   20
## 
## $Slot6
##     Pos              Player ADP_est ADP_Rank     HALF Slot
## 122  RB        Alvin Kamara    6.00        6 245.4832    6
## 83   RB Christian Mccaffrey   20.15       20 213.4223   19
## 
## $Slot7
##     Pos              Player ADP_est ADP_Rank     HALF Slot
## 121  RB         Kareem Hunt    9.30        9 229.6042    7
## 83   RB Christian Mccaffrey   20.15       20 213.4223   18
## 
## $Slot8
##     Pos              Player ADP_est ADP_Rank     HALF Slot
## 121  RB         Kareem Hunt    9.30        9 229.6042    8
## 83   RB Christian Mccaffrey   20.15       20 213.4223   17
## 
## $Slot9
##     Pos              Player ADP_est ADP_Rank     HALF Slot
## 121  RB         Kareem Hunt    9.30        9 229.6042    9
## 83   RB Christian Mccaffrey   20.15       20 213.4223   16
## 
## $Slot10
##    Pos              Player ADP_est ADP_Rank     HALF Slot
## 78  RB   Leonard Fournette   10.00       10 213.3087   10
## 83  RB Christian Mccaffrey   20.15       20 213.4223   15
## 
## $Slot11
##    Pos              Player ADP_est ADP_Rank     HALF Slot
## 79  RB       Melvin Gordon   10.45       11 212.0997   11
## 83  RB Christian Mccaffrey   20.15       20 213.4223   14
## 
## $Slot12
##    Pos              Player ADP_est ADP_Rank     HALF Slot
## 93  WR         Julio Jones   14.10       14 224.4879   12
## 83  RB Christian Mccaffrey   20.15       20 213.4223   13
There are some shortcomings though with using this basic optimization to inform your strategy. First of all, the thing you want to optimize is not all of your picks' pointsa more appropriate objective would be to draft in a way that will give you the eventual best starting lineup. This would ideally take into account the uncertainty of the projections, the fact that you can only start a limited number of each position, and the possibility of getting waiver wire adds. I'll show how I account for this below.

More Complex Case

For the more complicated case, my methodology will be to get an optimal lineup, but I will evaluate its performance not by the sum of the projected points, but rather by how strong it's mean-simulated top starting lineup is. I will explain this in depth later. To do this method though, I will first need estimates of the errors of the projections. It is widely assumed that RBs have errors with high variance while something like a TE has low variance, and so this should be accounted for when simulating the actual values from the projections.

Error Analysis

I summarize below the projection error (actual-projected) for 2009-2017, grouped by projection range and position. A negative mean-value means players have underperformed for that subgroup. A high SD value means players; performance has been more volatile in that subgroup: 
##    fantPts_bin Pos  meanError medianError  sdError   n
## 4      (25,75] DST   7.666667   -3.500000 33.10992   6
## 13    (75,125] DST  17.542373   12.000000 29.61336 118
## 5      (25,75]   K  13.788522   15.425605 42.57718  11
## 14    (75,125]   K  14.556467   16.501889 28.48010 198
## 22   (125,175]   K  -8.139669   -8.531961 28.08898  50
## 7      (25,75]  QB   7.924877   -9.800000 51.62458 125
## 16    (75,125]  QB   8.771959   -9.153795 84.60471  34
## 24   (125,175]  QB -20.094962  -49.006279 83.69827  52
## 28   (175,225]  QB   1.696868   16.909655 77.97935  83
## 32   (225,400]  QB   4.746088   17.668665 68.98852 142
## 8      (25,75]  RB   2.842122   -8.079204 42.24322 360
## 17    (75,125]  RB  -3.965397  -13.923055 59.31428 218
## 25   (125,175]  RB -24.732960  -23.050371 64.53592 184
## 29   (175,225]  RB -20.815804  -22.195431 80.09488 103
## 33   (225,400]  RB -52.632221  -40.454483 91.39643  37
## 9      (25,75]  TE  -2.415085  -10.941867 33.11226 343
## 18    (75,125]  TE  -4.810404   -3.372042 42.56975 164
## 26   (125,175]  TE -18.583065   -8.739259 52.57490  65
## 30   (175,225]  TE -18.295723  -22.789903 61.48846   8
## 10     (25,75]  WR   3.406541   -7.491818 42.56455 593
## 19    (75,125]  WR  -6.952610  -11.369156 51.59724 330
## 27   (125,175]  WR -11.229153  -10.060463 55.86669 233
## 31   (175,225]  WR -12.854190   -8.263119 57.03709 115
## 34   (225,400]  WR -21.528408  -10.719617 64.93034  23
Plotting the above standard deviations of the errors by position: I can also look at the plots of the actual data by subgroup: Looking at the above data and plots, I see how different positions have different error distributions. I initially was going to assume all errors are normally distributed, but looking at all plots I see that many of the subgroups are skewed right (ex: RBs 75-125) and some are normally distributed (WRs 125-175). In addition, there appears to be some bias as top RBs have seem to underperformed their projections and DSTs have overperformed my projections. For the bias, I can ignore it and chalk it up to sample size or I can un-bias my projections. This is definitely an important question because it would determine whether I take off points from the projections of the top RBs. I will first assume the projections are not biased and so shift all errors to be centered at 0. I outline the assumptions below. Assumption 1. I will assume the error of a player is randomly sampled from their corresponding error-bin, and I will add a constant to each error bin so that the errors of each bin have mean 0. Assumption 2. I also assume that you will be able to pick up undrafted players. I assume you will be able to get the third highest performing undrafted player at each position. This may be aggressive but it's likely that if you only need DST and TE mid-season, you will be able to get a strong one at both.

Simulation

Finally, I am ready to simulate a season from my optimal lineup. First I get the optimal picks at Slot=4/12, same as in base case: 
##     Pos              Player ADP_est ADP_Rank     HALF Slot
## 122  RB        Alvin Kamara    6.00      6.0 245.4832    4
## 77   RB     Jerick Mckinnon   20.60     22.0 194.1646   21
## 88   WR         Tyreek Hill   29.65     29.0 184.3552   28
## 90   WR Juju Smith Schuster   42.35     45.0 179.3604   45
## 106  QB      Russell Wilson   57.10     57.5 291.4859   52
## 109  QB          Cam Newton   74.05     76.0 274.0508   69
## 32   TE      Delanie Walker   79.15     80.0 132.7886   76
## 61   WR         Cooper Kupp  100.70    100.0 149.4343   93
## 42   WR      Robby Anderson  104.65    107.0 145.7251  100
## 62   WR    Sterling Shepard  119.10    125.0 139.7021  117
## 387  RB     Devontae Booker  119.40    126.0 122.6159  124
## 40   WR    Rishard Matthews  142.75    146.0 133.4577  141
## 30   RB         James White  149.30    155.0 137.4044  148
## 315 DST                 Pit  163.35    186.0 122.0000  165
## 5     K     Harrison Butker      NA    500.0 145.3158  172
Then I can get the top starting lineup from 1 simulation, determining simulated points by sampling from players' error bin. Projected Points=HALF. Simulated Points=Sim: 
##    Pos              Player ADP_est ADP_Rank      HALF Slot fantPts_bin     error      Sim
## 1   RB        Alvin Kamara    6.00        6 245.48323    4   (225,400] 106.48421 351.9674
## 6   QB          Cam Newton   74.05       76 274.05084   69   (225,400]  74.55869 348.6095
## 11  RB     Devontae Booker  119.40      126 122.61589  124    (75,125] 131.72378 254.3397
## 4   WR Juju Smith Schuster   42.35       45 179.36045   45   (175,225]  71.61998 250.9804
## 3   WR         Tyreek Hill   29.65       29 184.35515   28   (175,225]  58.11860 242.4737
## 8   WR         Cooper Kupp  100.70      100 149.43428   93   (125,175]  57.80754 207.2418
## 19  TE       Garrett Celek      NA      500  41.81859   NA     (25,75] 123.57666 165.3952
## 21   K      Roberto Aguayo      NA      500 111.81309   NA    (75,125]  52.77177 164.5849
## 14 DST                 Pit  163.35      186 122.00000  165    (75,125]  16.45763 138.4576
Undrafted players can end up in the top lineup for a given simulation if their HALF+error is better than the players I drafted. Finally, I repeat the simulation a large number of times to get the mean-simulated optimal lineup from a set of picks. The sum of the top lineup will stabilize to a given value as I repeat the top-lineup simulation a large number of times.

Optimizing Parameters

The last step of the system is to test different parameters. I can specify things like number of players to take at each position or whether I should lock in a certain player. I repeat the above simulation many times and I want to find the parameters that result in the best mean-simulated optimal lineup. Below I plot the simulation results for different parameter combinations. In the plot you can see the effect of different actions. For example, it suggests you should definitely take 2 QBs, as the 1 QB test (case 6) performs very poorly. Taking Antonio Brown instead of Kamara in round 1 slightly decreases the median-simulated starting lineup, despite Antonio Brown's raw projection actually being higher than Kamara's. The planned draft from the optimal parameter combo (case 3) is shown below. 
getPicks(slot="Slot4", numRB=4, numWR = 6,numTE=1,numK=1,numQB=2, numDST=1,numFLEX = 0,shift=0,  out=c(), fix=c(), scoring='HALF')

##     Pos              Player ADP_est ADP_Rank     HALF Slot
## 122  RB        Alvin Kamara    6.00      6.0 245.4832    4
## 77   RB     Jerick Mckinnon   20.60     22.0 194.1646   21
## 88   WR         Tyreek Hill   29.65     29.0 184.3552   28
## 90   WR Juju Smith Schuster   42.35     45.0 179.3604   45
## 106  QB      Russell Wilson   57.10     57.5 291.4859   52
## 109  QB          Cam Newton   74.05     76.0 274.0508   69
## 32   TE      Delanie Walker   79.15     80.0 132.7886   76
## 61   WR         Cooper Kupp  100.70    100.0 149.4343   93
## 42   WR      Robby Anderson  104.65    107.0 145.7251  100
## 62   WR    Sterling Shepard  119.10    125.0 139.7021  117
## 387  RB     Devontae Booker  119.40    126.0 122.6159  124
## 40   WR    Rishard Matthews  142.75    146.0 133.4577  141
## 30   RB         James White  149.30    155.0 137.4044  148
## 315 DST                 Pit  163.35    186.0 122.0000  165
## 5     K     Harrison Butker      NA    500.0 145.3158  172

Analyzing Bias

Before I mentioned that the projections I am using have been biased for certain positions. For the last part of my analysis I'd like to see how the bias might affect my results. Looking at the errors, I'm going to create a shifted projection HALF2 that accounts for bias: 
head(adp[, !grepl("STD|PPR", colnames(adp))], 10)

##     fantPts_bin Pos            Player ADP_est ADPSD_est ADP_Rank     HALF meanError    HALF2
## 120   (225,400]  RB       Todd Gurley    1.85      0.90        1 286.9787 -52.63222 234.3465
## 119   (225,400]  RB       Leveon Bell    2.25      1.00        2 285.5994 -52.63222 232.9672
## 118   (225,400]  RB   Ezekiel Elliott    3.40      1.35        3 245.7330 -52.63222 193.1008
## 117   (225,400]  RB     David Johnson    3.90      1.10        4 237.7158 -52.63222 185.0835
## 123   (225,400]  WR     Antonio Brown    5.10      1.40        5 244.1744 -21.52841 222.6460
## 122   (225,400]  RB      Alvin Kamara    6.00      1.25        6 245.4832 -52.63222 192.8510
## 82    (175,225]  RB    Saquon Barkley    6.80      1.80        7 221.9244 -20.81580 201.1086
## 87    (175,225]  WR   Deandre Hopkins    8.80      1.90        8 217.1364 -12.85419 204.2822
## 121   (225,400]  RB       Kareem Hunt    9.30      1.75        9 229.6042 -52.63222 176.9720
## 78    (175,225]  RB Leonard Fournette   10.00      1.80       10 213.3087 -20.81580 192.4929
From the error analysis, top-rated RB's have underperformed greatly, based on a sample size of around 40. With the bias-adjusted projections, I am now projecting Antonio Brown to do much better than some of the top RBs. I'll now redo the initial optimization, using these new projections: 
#getPicks() with "HALF2" scoring
getPicks(slot="Slot4", numRB=4, numWR = 6,numTE=1,numK=1,numQB=2, numDST=1,numFLEX = 0,shift=0,  out=c(), fix=c(), scoring='HALF2')

##     Pos              Player ADP_est ADP_Rank     HALF    HALF2 Slot
## 123  WR       Antonio Brown    5.10      5.0 244.1744 222.6460    4
## 77   RB     Jerick Mckinnon   20.60     22.0 194.1646 173.3488   21
## 88   WR         Tyreek Hill   29.65     29.0 184.3552 171.5010   28
## 90   WR Juju Smith Schuster   42.35     45.0 179.3604 166.5063   45
## 106  QB      Russell Wilson   57.10     57.5 291.4859 296.2320   52
## 109  QB          Cam Newton   74.05     76.0 274.0508 278.7969   69
## 61   WR         Cooper Kupp  100.70    100.0 149.4343 138.2051   76
## 42   WR      Robby Anderson  104.65    107.0 145.7251 134.4959   93
## 384  RB        Duke Johnson  106.70    109.0 121.1553 117.1899  100
## 387  RB     Devontae Booker  119.40    126.0 122.6159 118.6505  117
## 396  TE          Jack Doyle  127.25    131.5 117.6762 112.8658  124
## 40   WR    Rishard Matthews  142.75    146.0 133.4577 122.2286  141
## 30   RB         James White  149.30    155.0 137.4044 112.6714  148
## 315 DST                 Pit  163.35    186.0 122.0000 139.5424  165
## 356   K      Matthew Prater  169.30    196.0 124.8721 139.4285  172
The optimal solution for the base case changes in favor of picking Antonio Brown in Round 1. Next I repeat the parameter optimization to see the effect of my projections' bias on that: The results now are less clear on whether to pick an WR in Round 1, although some conclusions remain the same such as to take a backup QB, and don't go zero-RB. Looking at the top 2 picks by round for the bias-adjusted projections, you can see how the suggested picks changed from before, and the first two rounds suggest more of a mix of picks: 
sapply(paste0("Slot", 1:12), function(x) getPicks(slot=x, numRB=6, numWR = 4,numTE=1,numK=1,numQB=2, numDST=1,numFLEX = 0,shift=0,  out=c(), fix=c(), scoring='HALF2')[1:2,],simplify = FALSE,USE.NAMES = TRUE)

## $Slot1
##     Pos            Player ADP_est ADP_Rank     HALF    HALF2 Slot
## 120  RB       Todd Gurley    1.85        1 286.9787 234.3465    1
## 84   TE Robert Gronkowski   23.70       25 176.8560 158.5603   24
## 
## $Slot2
##     Pos            Player ADP_est ADP_Rank     HALF    HALF2 Slot
## 119  RB       Leveon Bell    2.25        2 285.5994 232.9672    2
## 84   TE Robert Gronkowski   23.70       25 176.8560 158.5603   23
## 
## $Slot3
##     Pos          Player ADP_est ADP_Rank     HALF    HALF2 Slot
## 123  WR   Antonio Brown     5.1        5 244.1744 222.6460    3
## 77   RB Jerick Mckinnon    20.6       22 194.1646 173.3488   22
## 
## $Slot4
##     Pos          Player ADP_est ADP_Rank     HALF    HALF2 Slot
## 123  WR   Antonio Brown     5.1        5 244.1744 222.6460    4
## 77   RB Jerick Mckinnon    20.6       22 194.1646 173.3488   21
## 
## $Slot5
##    Pos              Player ADP_est ADP_Rank     HALF    HALF2 Slot
## 82  RB      Saquon Barkley    6.80        7 221.9244 201.1086    5
## 83  RB Christian Mccaffrey   20.15       20 213.4223 192.6065   20
## 
## $Slot6
##    Pos              Player ADP_est ADP_Rank     HALF    HALF2 Slot
## 82  RB      Saquon Barkley    6.80        7 221.9244 201.1086    6
## 83  RB Christian Mccaffrey   20.15       20 213.4223 192.6065   19
## 
## $Slot7
##    Pos              Player ADP_est ADP_Rank     HALF    HALF2 Slot
## 82  RB      Saquon Barkley    6.80        7 221.9244 201.1086    7
## 83  RB Christian Mccaffrey   20.15       20 213.4223 192.6065   18
## 
## $Slot8
##    Pos              Player ADP_est ADP_Rank     HALF    HALF2 Slot
## 78  RB   Leonard Fournette   10.00       10 213.3087 192.4929    8
## 83  RB Christian Mccaffrey   20.15       20 213.4223 192.6065   17
## 
## $Slot9
##    Pos              Player ADP_est ADP_Rank     HALF    HALF2 Slot
## 78  RB   Leonard Fournette   10.00       10 213.3087 192.4929    9
## 83  RB Christian Mccaffrey   20.15       20 213.4223 192.6065   16
## 
## $Slot10
##    Pos              Player ADP_est ADP_Rank     HALF    HALF2 Slot
## 78  RB   Leonard Fournette   10.00       10 213.3087 192.4929   10

## 
## $Slot11
##    Pos              Player ADP_est ADP_Rank     HALF    HALF2 Slot
## 79  RB       Melvin Gordon   10.45       11 212.0997 191.2839   11
## 83  RB Christian Mccaffrey   20.15       20 213.4223 192.6065   14
## 
## $Slot12
##    Pos              Player ADP_est ADP_Rank     HALF    HALF2 Slot
## 93  WR         Julio Jones   14.10       14 224.4879 211.6337   12
## 83  RB Christian Mccaffrey   20.15       20 213.4223 192.6065   13

Conclusion

In conclusion, I created a system that optimizes to get the best eventual starting lineup for fantasy football. In testing different strategies, it seems you should definitely draft 2 QBs, you should not do zero-RB, and it is unclear if you should draft RB first. The main flaw still remaining in all of this is the uncertainty in opponent picks. If an optimal strategy depends on getting a high value QB in round 10 for example, it should factor in what happens if someone else takes the QB. I will talk about that in a future post. [1]:Yahoo default is 12-team league with 15 picks per team. Positions=1 QB, 2 WR, 2 RB, 1 TE, 1 FLEX, 1 DST, 1 K. Scoring = .5 PPR

item.title: Fantasy Football - Examining Projection Error
item.dc:creator: dlm1223@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
I've been analyzing optimal draft strategy, but an important question is how player's projection error is exactly distributed, and so I will examine it closely for this post. For this analysis I gathered historical preseason projections from fantasydata.com (2013-2017) and fantasyfootballanalytics.net (2008-2017). I also have my own projections that I predict out of sample (2009-2017). For scoring I am using Yahoo default which is .5 PPR. Below you can see how it looked for 2017, where fantPts_est is my own projections; fantPts_agg is the aggregated projection AKA a mean of fantPts_est, fantPts_FDATA, fantPts_FFA; and fantPts is the actual value: 
head(projections[projections$Season==2017, 1:9], 25)

##                      Player Season Pos Team fantPts_agg fantPts_est fantPts_FFA fantPts_FDATA fantPts
## 7             Aaron Rodgers   2017  QB  Gnb    331.6585    321.2330    336.1227        337.62  137.60
## 20                Tom Brady   2017  QB  Nwe    304.4849    278.9270    316.8878        317.64  303.88
## 22               Drew Brees   2017  QB  Nor    299.4926    289.3171    300.6608        308.50  270.56
## 28             Matthew Ryan   2017  QB  Atl    289.9405    285.9230    294.6984        289.20  242.10
## 34            David Johnson   2017  RB  Ari    285.6629    215.3941    319.9944        321.60   10.00
## 51           Russell Wilson   2017  QB  Sea    275.4901    229.0651    291.8451        305.56  360.92
## 55              Leveon Bell   2017  RB  Pit    273.7744    219.0544    302.0688        300.20  299.10
## 57               Derek Carr   2017  QB  Oak    272.5935    275.4151    262.1656        280.20  217.44
## 59             Dak Prescott   2017  QB  Dal    272.4938    260.7986    271.0029        285.68  279.66
## 67            Philip Rivers   2017  QB  Sdg    270.4540    276.5284    253.8137        281.02  282.40
## 73           Marcus Mariota   2017  QB  Ten    270.1098    257.8681    269.0413        283.42  225.48
## 84               Cam Newton   2017  QB  Car    267.2553    238.2751    275.7109        287.78  313.48
## 86           Jameis Winston   2017  QB  Tam    266.6491    236.0767    274.9507        288.92  222.66
## 89         Matthew Stafford   2017  QB  Det    264.4731    255.9761    264.6431        272.80  291.64
## 108            Kirk Cousins   2017  QB  Was    259.2463    227.3857    267.9131        282.44  298.62
## 114 Benjamin Roethlisberger   2017  QB  Pit    258.3333    251.4760    258.7439        264.78  272.74
## 149             Andy Dalton   2017  QB  Cin    246.4031    205.5009    256.6884        277.02  228.70
## 157             Eli Manning   2017  QB  Nyg    244.8885    244.1286    234.0368        256.50  210.32
## 167             Julio Jones   2017  WR  Atl    241.7634    232.5642    250.9625        247.40  207.90
## 172           Antonio Brown   2017  WR  Pit    240.7157    214.6243    266.8072        260.70  257.80
## 210           Carson Palmer   2017  QB  Ari    232.3541    202.6332    244.3893        250.04  109.32
## 213            Tyrod Taylor   2017  QB  Buf    232.1267    182.4278    257.5322        256.42  230.66
## 220            Carson Wentz   2017  QB  Phi    229.9481    188.4841    237.5002        263.86  282.74
## 245           Odell Beckham   2017  WR  Nyg    225.8783    214.7789    236.9776        239.70   61.50
## 273           Joseph Flacco   2017  QB  Bal    221.5028    202.0758    224.4725        237.96  196.04
For outside projections like ESPN, there has been evidence of over-projection. Also, this article from ffanalytics also looks at projection accuracy and bias and finds overprojection too. I'd like to fully examine error as a function of position and projection, so I bin the projections and positions and calculate the mean and sd of the errors for each group for 2009-2017, where a negative mean implies that players in that group underperformed their projection: 
##    fantPts_bin Pos  meanError medianError  sdError   n
## 4      (25,75] DST   7.666667   -3.500000 33.10992   6
## 13    (75,125] DST  17.542373   12.000000 29.61336 118
## 5      (25,75]   K  13.788522   15.425605 42.57718  11
## 14    (75,125]   K  14.556467   16.501889 28.48010 198
## 22   (125,175]   K  -8.139669   -8.531961 28.08898  50
## 7      (25,75]  QB   7.924877   -9.800000 51.62458 125
## 16    (75,125]  QB   8.771959   -9.153795 84.60471  34
## 24   (125,175]  QB -20.094962  -49.006279 83.69827  52
## 28   (175,225]  QB   1.696868   16.909655 77.97935  83
## 32   (225,400]  QB   4.746088   17.668665 68.98852 142
## 8      (25,75]  RB   2.842122   -8.079204 42.24322 360
## 17    (75,125]  RB  -3.965397  -13.923055 59.31428 218
## 25   (125,175]  RB -24.732960  -23.050371 64.53592 184
## 29   (175,225]  RB -20.815804  -22.195431 80.09488 103
## 33   (225,400]  RB -52.632221  -40.454483 91.39643  37
## 9      (25,75]  TE  -2.415085  -10.941867 33.11226 343
## 18    (75,125]  TE  -4.810404   -3.372042 42.56975 164
## 26   (125,175]  TE -18.583065   -8.739259 52.57490  65
## 30   (175,225]  TE -18.295723  -22.789903 61.48846   8
## 10     (25,75]  WR   3.406541   -7.491818 42.56455 593
## 19    (75,125]  WR  -6.952610  -11.369156 51.59724 330
## 27   (125,175]  WR -11.229153  -10.060463 55.86669 233
## 31   (175,225]  WR -12.854190   -8.263119 57.03709 115
## 34   (225,400]  WR -21.528408  -10.719617 64.93034  23
My calculations confirm that there is a lot of over-projection going on, however it is different for different subgroups. For example top RB's (225,400] have underperformed by around 50 points on average. I can also look at the actual plots of the data by subgroup: And I can look at standard deviations of the errors by position: Looking at the above data and plots, I see how different positions have different error distributions. I initially was going to assume all errors are normally distributed, but looking at all plots I see that many of the subgroups are skewed right (ex: RBs 75-125) and some are normally distributed (WRs 125-175). In addition, there is bias as top RBs have greatly underperformed their projections. For the bias, I can ignore it and chalk it up to sample size, or I can try to adjust the projection. This is definitely an important question because it would determine whether I take off points from the projections of the top RBs. Below I plot the top RBs across time: For fun, I'll also show a plot of the top WRs: The cumulative mean shown in blue shows how this under-performance trend has been pretty consistent for RB's. If the projections didn't overpredict, the blue line would be in line with the red line. Like RB's,WR's have underperformed, but by less (-21 vs -52). This year these top RBs include Leveon Bell, Gurley, Kamara, Zeke, David Johnson, and Kareem Hunt and the only top WR is Antonio Brown. Looking at the projections for this year, the question now is whether to adjust these outside projections based on this bias. 
##              Player Pos Team fantPts_est fantPts_FDATA fantPts_agg
## 33      Todd Gurley  RB  Lar    214.3362         323.3    286.9787
## 35      Leveon Bell  RB  Pit    217.3983         319.7    285.5994
## 153 Ezekiel Elliott  RB  Dal    215.7991         260.7    245.7330
## 155    Alvin Kamara  RB  Nor    193.6497         271.4    245.4832
## 160   Antonio Brown  WR  Pit    227.9489         260.4    244.1744
## 187   David Johnson  RB  Ari    166.5473         273.3    237.7158
## 227     Kareem Hunt  RB  Kan    204.8126         242.0    229.6042
Your optimal draft decisions are a function of where you have players projected, and so in a future post I will show how this bias would affect your draft decisions.

item.title: Optimization for Fantasy Football Snake Drafts (Part 2) - Probabilistic Opponent Picks
item.dc:creator: dlm1223@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
• Background
  • Draft Methodology
  • Parameter Tuning (2 WR Leagues)
  • Parameter Tuning (3 WR Leagues)
  • Conclusion

Background

In my last postI tested different draft strategies for optimizing draft picks for Yahoo fantasy football leagues. A fantasy football draft can be viewed as an optimization problem, where you are maximizing the sum of the projected points of the players you select. Below is a summary of the steps in my first post:
  1. Maximize the projected points of my draft picks subject to players' average draft positions ("ADP"), and subject to constraints on number of players at each position to take
  2. Run simulations of the optimal draft chosen in Step 1 to get the mean simulated starting lineup from the specified players. You draft 15 players but you only are allowed to start 9. Ex: Taking 3 QBs is probably a poor decision since you only can put 1 in your starting lineup, while other positions like WR you need to start more.
  3. Decide the optimal draft strategy based on which strategy from Step 1 provided the highest mean-simulated starting lineup
Instead of just using Step 1, simulating it's results in step 2 allows you to account for a variety of important factors. For example, Step 2 accounts forthe fact that a RB has higher variance, and how in your starting lineup you need to start a higher number of certain positions like WRs. The main thing I was missing in my first post though was the fact that average draft position is probabilistic and not fixed. If a player has an ADP of 4.1 (round 4, pick 1), my original system would assume they will always be there at 3.11, but in reality there is a good chance they won't be there, and so In this post I repeat my first post, but account for opponent pick uncertainty. If you only care about the results just skip to the conclusion.

Draft Methodology

My system is very similar to my previous post. Like last time, I start off with a dataframe of players with their ADPs: 
head(adp[, c("Player", "Pos", "ADP_est", "ADPSD_est", "ADP_Rank", "HALF", "STD", "PPR")], 25)

##                  Player Pos ADP_est ADPSD_est ADP_Rank     HALF      STD      PPR
## 649         Todd Gurley  RB    1.85      0.90        1 286.9787 278.7288 295.3511
## 440         Leveon Bell  RB    2.25      1.00        2 285.5994 276.2004 294.9930
## 258     Ezekiel Elliott  RB    3.40      1.35        3 245.7330 240.7392 250.8822
## 188       David Johnson  RB    3.90      1.10        4 237.7158 232.9482 242.4851
## 39        Antonio Brown  WR    5.10      1.40        5 244.1744 220.2120 268.1369
## 27         Alvin Kamara  RB    6.00      1.25        6 245.4832 235.7970 255.2076
## 599      Saquon Barkley  RB    6.80      1.80        7 221.9244 216.4002 227.4485
## 193     Deandre Hopkins  WR    8.80      1.90        8 217.1364 196.1761 238.0967
## 400         Kareem Hunt  RB    9.30      1.75        9 229.6042 222.5463 236.7176
## 437   Leonard Fournette  RB   10.00      1.80       10 213.3087 207.6375 219.0514
## 494       Melvin Gordon  RB   10.45      2.05       11 212.0997 205.3586 218.8665
## 533       Odell Beckham  WR   11.50      2.05       12 196.8351 178.9319 214.7382
## 167         Dalvin Cook  RB   12.90      2.00       13 204.0279 199.3044 208.7746
## 386         Julio Jones  WR   14.10      2.15       14 224.4879 202.2329 246.7428
## 507      Michael Thomas  WR   15.90      2.30       15 208.1782 188.1379 228.2185
## 223     Devonta Freeman  RB   17.55      2.50       16 202.7999 196.5961 209.0049
## 186       Davante Adams  WR   18.10      2.40       17 176.9410 161.1901 192.6918
## 403        Keenan Allen  WR   18.40      2.50       18 193.9841 176.8953 211.0729
## 439        Lesean Mccoy  RB   18.85      2.90       19 195.3838 189.0302 201.7331
## 133 Christian Mccaffrey  RB   20.15      3.10       20 213.4223 203.1830 223.5142
## 10             Aj Green  WR   20.55      2.25       21 185.0449 168.3994 201.6903
## 341     Jerick Mckinnon  RB   20.60      3.50       22 194.1646 187.8265 200.4310
## 359       Jordan Howard  RB   22.10      3.05       23 170.0072 166.0453 174.0318
## 500       Michael Evans  WR   23.55      2.75       24 182.9814 164.8576 201.1052
## 571   Robert Gronkowski  TE   23.70      3.65       25 176.8560 160.0528 193.6592
In the first post, I just optimized all my picks at once to maximize total points. This time, because actual draft position will be decided probabilistically, I can't decide all of my picks at once because ADP is not precisely known. To get a probabilistic draft order, I will simulate the draft using the ADP_est (mean ADP) and ADPSD_est (sd ADP). When it's my pick, I optimize my remaining picks based on who is available (same as Step 1). However, I only store the first player from this. I then repeat everything--I simulate more picks, then run the optimization for my remaining picks, returning only the first player, etc., until I've selected all of my players. Below is an example draft with the specified number of players to take: 
simDraft(slot="Slot4",scoring="HALF",numRB=4, numWR=6, numTE=1, numQB=2,numK=1,numDST=1,  numFLEX=0, out=c())  

##                 Player ADP_est ADPSD_est Pos ADP_Rank     HALF      STD      PPR    ADP_sim Slot
## 1         Alvin Kamara    6.00      1.25  RB      6.0 245.4832 235.7970 255.2076   4.974415    4
## 2  Christian Mccaffrey   20.15      3.10  RB     20.0 213.4223 203.1830 223.5142  21.991094   21
## 3          Tyreek Hill   29.65      3.40  WR     29.0 184.3552 165.8817 202.8286  28.024290   28
## 4          Mark Ingram   48.15      5.65  RB     50.0 154.7205 148.2986 161.1322  53.128259   45
## 5     Demaryius Thomas   46.00      4.50  WR     47.5 166.1272 150.4034 181.8510  49.458398   52
## 6         Carson Wentz   67.30      7.60  QB     68.0 287.7429 287.7384 287.7473  78.438217   69
## 7       Delanie Walker   79.15      8.00  TE     80.0 132.7886 120.0308 145.5463  74.433832   76
## 8          Cooper Kupp  100.70      8.40  WR    100.0 149.4343 133.5061 165.3624  96.723435   93
## 9       Robby Anderson  104.65      8.20  WR    107.0 145.7251 129.9623 161.4879 110.527001  100
## 10    Matthew Stafford  104.50     10.40  QB    106.0 268.6257 268.6231 268.6284 122.879788  117
## 11    Sterling Shepard  119.10      9.10  WR    125.0 139.7021 124.8505 154.5536 118.188264  124
## 12    Rishard Matthews  142.75     11.85  WR    146.0 133.4577 119.3678 147.5476 133.852795  141
## 13        Bilal Powell  148.95     13.15  RB    153.5 107.4629 102.5156 112.3073 144.767401  148
## 14                 Pit  163.35     10.80 DST    186.0 122.0000 122.0000 122.0000 161.635450  165
## 15     Harrison Butker      NA        NA   K    500.0 145.3158 145.3158 145.3158 500.000000  172
You can see above that even though McCaffrey has the 20th ranked ADP, I am still able to get him with my round 2 pick (pick 21) in this draft simulation, something I wouldn't have been able to account for in my original post. I repeat the draft several times to get several potential drafts given my specified parameters. 
drafts<-replicate(250,  simDraft(slot="Slot4", scoring="HALF"), simplify = F)
Becker & Sun (2013)[1] also did a draft algorithm with probabilistic picks, which had some useful ideas. One thing they did was have a parameter called alpha that constrained how to view the pool of players that opponents will pick (See section 4.2 of their paper). The alpha parameter basically creates what is called an uncertainty set, andessentially determines how conservative or risky to plan your future picks.It's a bit confusing, but it is the same as using the shift parameter from my last post, which just shifted everyone's ADP up or down. Alpha is now just another parameter that I can change and see how it effects the eventual simulated starting lineup results. In this version of my system, I now have several potential drafts for a specified set of parameters. In my first post, step 1 provided 1 optimal draft given my parameters, but this time I now have multiple ones for Step 1. Given these drafts, I can now proceed and apply the simulations to each of them (Step 2 from earlier) to get mean simulated top lineups for each of my probabilistic drafts. In this case, I'd have 250 drafts x 100 sims = 25,000 total simulated lineups for one set of specified drafting parameters. 
simScores<-lapply(drafts, function(x)replicate(100,simSeason(x, scoring="HALF")))

Parameter Tuning (2 WR Leagues)

Finally, I am ready to test out different drafting parameters (ex: numWR, numRB, alpha, zeroRB, zeroQB,alpha, etc.). Below are plots of the mean-simulated starting lineups for different drafting parameters. My sample size is 250 simulated drafts x 100 simulated seasons = 25,000 simulations for each specified parameter. I chose this number because it was sufficient for the mean-simulated lineup results to stabilize. I adjust the projections to account for the fact that RBs tend to be overprojected. Below are the simulation results for each draft parameter specification: These results above are similar to my last post. Zero RB does pretty bad (case 11), and not taking a backup QB (case 9) also does bad. Like last time, I am still unsure about round 1: The injury potential of the top RBs makes it less clear if fading RB in R1 (case 4) is a bad move compared to fading WR (case 5). I also plot scoring by draft slot: The results are less clear on who you should take after you get past the top 2 running backs Leveon/Gurley. Being at pick 4, the system says Antonio Brown wouldn't be a bad pick.

Parameter Tuning (3 WR Leagues)

In addition to 2 WR Leagues, which is Yahoo default, I also test 3 WR Leagues, which is what my league is. Since you need to start at least 3 WR's (can put one in the flex spot too), I suspect the results may now favor taking a WR in the first round. I repeat the exact same analysis as before: And the results by draft slot:
The results for the 3WR leagues look pretty similar to the 2WR leagues. You can see that the y-axis is greater for the 3WR leagues, because your mean-simulated lineup will be higher if you get to start an extra player.

Conclusion

In this post, I expanded from my last post and outlined my final system for optimizing draft picks. I tested 2 WR and 3 WR fantasy leagues. The results support the results from my last post in which I did not account for opponent draft uncertainty. Things I can say definitively are that youshould not go zero-RB and you should definitely take a backup QB. The results are still unclear on which way to go in round 1. For me, picking at pick 4 in a 3 WR league, if Leveon/Gurley fell to me, I would definitely take them, and if not then I am not sure yet. Leveon/Gurley seem to be the best picks, but after that, RB vs WR becomes less clearcut. Finally, one final thing that my system does not account for is handcuffing a running back i.e. taking his backup. I could probably get David Johnson's backup in the 15th round, and so that might be something I could do to reduce the risk of my first round RB. Given that fact, I may lean towards RB in round 1 at pick 4. Thanks for reading! [1]: My methodology was similar to Becker and Sun in that we both simulated the draft, but they created an optimization that maximized expected number of wins, basing that on projected weekly points and estimated head to head fantasy football league-matchups. My methodology bases the optimization on projected total points and tries to get the best starting lineup so its objective is different.

item.title: Does Preseason Matter? Analyzing Preseason NFL Data and Vegas Win Totals
item.dc:creator: dlm1223@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
For this post I'll examine preseason NFL data and show how it is possibly useful in predicting how a team will perform in the upcoming season. I scraped preseason scores from ESPN.com for 2003-present. For each team, I have the game results by quarter for all of their preseason games. I can then aggregate by year and team to get different summary stats:

Team Year ActualWins Win.Total Preseason.Diff Preseason.Diff.X1 Preseason.Diff.X12 Preseason.Diff.X123
Ari 2003 4 5.0 33 10 10 27
Atl 2003 5 9.5 -29 -2 0 -41
Bal 2003 10 7.5 -25 10 -20 -16
Buf 2003 6 8.5 -2 21 -10 -23
Car 2003 11 7.5 50 -4 2 22


PreseasonDiff.X1 means their score differential in preseason in the first quarter of games only, and X123 would mean for quarters1-3, etc. I also show the Vegas Win-Total and actual regular season wins taken from sportsoddhistory.com. Next, I look at correlations:

I can also visaulize it a different way..below I plot the rate-of a team hitting the over on their win total, broken down by their preseason Q1-3 differential.


I can also plot the Q1-2 results:


Clearly there is a correlation of preseason results to regular season actual wins, even when controlling for the vegas win-total. For the plots, the reason I plotted multiple ones like cutting off at 2013 or using Q1-2 is to test the sensitivity of my results to these changed parameters, and try to reduce the chance I'm overfitting the analysis. I decide to now create an updated win-total estimate using the Preseason.Diff.X123 (point differential in the preseason with the 4th quarter removed), and I scale it by year on a range of 1-16 so that it will line up and be comparable with the Vegas-win total.

range01 <- function(x){(x-min(x))/(max(x)-min(x))}
aggYear<-ddply(aggYear, .(Year), mutate,
               Preseason.Diff.X123.alt=range01(Preseason.Diff.X123)*16)

summary(lm(ActualWins~Win.Total+Preseason.Diff.X123.alt+0, data=aggYear))

## 
## Call:
## lm(formula = ActualWins ~ Win.Total + Preseason.Diff.X123.alt + 
##     0, data = aggYear)
## 
## Residuals:
##     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
## -8.2514 -2.0182  0.1493  2.0226  7.1020 
## 
## Coefficients:
##                         Estimate Std. Error t value             Pr(>|t|)    
## Win.Total                0.84496    0.03319  25.456 < 0.0000000000000002 ***
## Preseason.Diff.X123.alt  0.13281    0.02996   4.433            0.0000115 ***
## ---
## Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
## 
## Residual standard error: 2.749 on 478 degrees of freedom
##   (32 observations deleted due to missingness)
## Multiple R-squared:  0.8976, Adjusted R-squared:  0.8972 
## F-statistic:  2095 on 2 and 478 DF,  p-value: < 0.00000000000000022


I now define Win.Total.Agg as 15% the PreseasonDiff.123 (scaled) and 85% of the vegas win.total:

cor(aggYear$ActualWins, aggYear$Win.Total.Agg, use="pairwise.complete.obs")

## [1] 0.4727425

cor(aggYear$ActualWins, aggYear$Win.Total, use="pairwise.complete.obs")

## [1] 0.443447


The correlaton looks good, so I want to see it in practice. Vegas's cut for betting on the over/under of a win-total is often something like -130, meaning I get $100 back on a $130 bet aka .77 per 1 dollar invested. I place a bet in whichever direction the win.total.agg is:

Team Year Win.Total Preseason.Diff.X123.alt Win.Total.Agg Bet ActualWins Bet.Result Bet.Odds Profit
449 Ari 2017 8.5 7.053763 8.283065 Under 8 Correct 140 1.4000000
450 Atl 2017 9.5 6.021505 8.978226 Under 10 Incorrect -110 -1.0000000
451 Bal 2017 8.5 14.451613 9.392742 Over 9 Correct 130 1.3000000
452 Buf 2017 6.5 7.225807 6.608871 Over 9 Correct 130 1.3000000
453 Car 2017 9.0 10.322581 9.198387 Over 11 Correct -120 0.8333333
454 Chi 2017 5.5 7.913978 5.862097 Over 5 Incorrect 105 -1.0000000
455 Cin 2017 8.5 7.913978 8.412097 Under 7 Correct -140 0.7142857
456 Cle 2017 4.5 11.526882 5.554032 Over 0 Incorrect -180 -1.0000000
457 Dal 2017 9.5 6.709677 9.081452 Under 9 Correct -140 0.7142857
458 Den 2017 8.0 15.311828 9.096774 Over 5 Incorrect 100 -1.0000000


And looking at the results:

results<-aggYear[aggYear$Year!=2018& !is.na(aggYear$Over.Odds), ]

table(results$Bet.Result) # success rate=251/(251+176)~59%

## 
##   Correct Incorrect      Push 
##       251       176        20

sum(results$Profit)/length(results$Profit) #total ROI~10% on each dollar invested

## [1] 0.1021804

sum(results$Profit[results$Bet.Odds>=(-100)])/length(results$Profit[results$Bet.Odds>=(-100)]) #total ROI, only bet if odds are 1:1 or better

## [1] 0.2335664

#ROI by year
ddply(results, .(Year), summarize, 
      ROI=((sum(Profit))/length(Profit)), 
      numBets=length(Profit), 
      ROI2=(sum(Profit[Bet.Odds>=-100]))/length(Profit[Bet.Odds>=-100]))

##    Year         ROI numBets        ROI2
## 1  2003  0.21927818      32  0.07500000
## 2  2004 -0.25614797      32  0.20909091
## 3  2005  0.06578954      32 -0.12142857
## 4  2006  0.06518840      32  0.20909091
## 5  2007  0.33610737      32  0.61250000
## 6  2009  0.06175044      32  0.17142857
## 7  2010 -0.08123581      32  0.39375000
## 8  2011 -0.05110689      31 -0.23333333
## 9  2012  0.20686262      32 -0.05555556
## 10 2013  0.22513906      32  0.59000000
## 11 2014  0.09314274      32  0.20714286
## 12 2015  0.13213162      32  0.23125000
## 13 2016  0.27736296      32  0.41666667
## 14 2017  0.13147321      32  0.25357143


The results look pretty good. 59% success rate, ~10% ROI per dollar on average. If I constrain it to only bet if the odds are 1:1 or better, the results look even better, however obviously the sample decreases. Obviously all of this is in-sample.

Lastly, why would I share it if I think this might work? The answer is that since there are only around 32 bets available, and because of this small sample size and possibility of overfitting, I don't really intend to bet a large sum of money on this. If this was a bet I could place hundreds of times, then it would be more useful and I wouldn't share it. It might be useful for is to incorporate in a game-prediction model, which is something I've looked into, as it would allow for a larger sample size. If someone is considering placing a bet on a Win-Total though, this is definitely a good thing to look at. Check back once the preseason is over and I'll show which bets I suggest.

Update 8/31/18:

The preseason ended yesterday. Below is a table of the results, along with my updated Win-Total Estimates. These odds are taken from oddshark.com. While my system has worked no matter the bet odds, I'd say if you are going to place a bet or two, I'd stick to the ones that have the best odds. In this case, some ones with good odds are: ATL-Under 9 (+130) and TB-Over 6.5 (+130).

Team Year Win.Total Preseason.Diff.X12 Preseason.Diff.X123 Win.Total.Agg Bet Bet.Odds
481 Ari 2018 5.5 39 38 6.583197 Over -200
482 Atl 2018 9.0 -34 -48 7.866393 Under 130
483 Bal 2018 8.0 25 63 9.200000 Over -165
484 Buf 2018 6.0 -27 -28 5.709836 Under -175
485 Car 2018 9.0 -18 -9 8.633607 Under -205
486 Chi 2018 6.5 12 12 6.921721 Over -140

490 Den 2018 7.0 10 34 7.779508 Over -170
491 Det 2018 7.5 -52 -59 6.375000 Under -115
492 Gnb 2018 10.0 21 25 10.152459 Over -125
493 Hou 2018 8.5 11 7 8.523361 Over -145
494 Ind 2018 6.5 -10 -9 6.508607 Over 110
495 Jax 2018 9.0 4 23 9.263115 Over -120
496 Kan 2018 8.5 -29 -19 8.011885 Under -125
497 Lar 2018 10.0 -25 -31 9.050820 Under 105
498 Mia 2018 6.5 14 9 6.862705 Over -135

500 Nor 2018 9.5 5 10 9.432377 Under 110
501 Nwe 2018 11.0 -3 -4 10.431967 Under 110

510 Tam 2018 6.5 40 15 6.980738 Over 130

item.title: Finding an Edge in Fantasy Football
item.dc:creator: dlm1223@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
Statistics have become popular for fantasy football but it's not necessarily a guarantee that analytics are better than just using the eye test, or consensus opinion, etc. In this post I'll compare ADP to outside projections to see where ADP has inefficiencies and where there might be edges in projecting players. I was able to get projections from 2012-present from fantasyfootballanalytics.net and from fftoday.com, and ADP data from ffcalculator.com. I also have my own aggregated projections. ffanalytics.net is an aggregated projection source where they tried to maximize accuracy and so I think it will be a pretty good source to use. All together I have a dataframe like this:

Player Year ADP_half fantPts_FFTODAY fantPts_FFA fantPts_agg fantPts
346 David Johnson 2017 1.45 321.5 317.8344 286.9557 10.0
854 Leveon Bell 2017 2.25 286.1 302.0688 277.3133 299.1
100 Antonio Brown 2017 4.85 257.9 260.9605 239.8764 257.8
729 Julio Jones 2017 5.50 250.7 250.9625 231.3079 207.9
1025 Odell Beckham 2017 6.60 248.7 234.1210 219.3702 61.5

Note: all projections are Half-PPR Yahoo Scoring. Next, I'll plot the accuracy of the projections for players who were drafted:

The above plot shows how third-party ranks have performed relative to players' ADP rank. Projections have outperformed draft order for WR/TE/QB, but other positions like RB have been harder to gain an edge. However, while it does look like there is inefficiency in things like WR/TE ADP, anyone who has played fantasy knows that ADP in later rounds is often guided by who has higher upside, and so ADP rank is not exactly a ranking of who will finish highest. To account for this, I'd like to see the effect if I just limit it to top 12 DST/K/QB/TE, top 24 RB, and top 36 WR (ranked by ADP), AKA the starting players, so I do that below:

The above plot shows similar trends to the first. I should mention that for these plots, I am converting the outside projections into ranks to make it more comparable– the results if I didn't do this were similar so I just left those plots off. From these above plots, I have the following takeways:

  • DST=impossible to project and a waste of a pick.
  • K=worth a pick since easier to predict, ADP is similarly accurate as projections
  • RB=ADP is similarly as accurate as any projection source, so not much edge. Also, hard to predict
  • QB= hard to predict, small edge might be possible
  • WR/TE= easiest to predict and edge appears possible using projections

Overall, ADP i.e. consensus opinion is pretty accurate for positions like RB. On the other hand, WR/TE's benefit the most from taking an analytical approach. Below I show some more plots..Here I examinine the WR projections further to see how they have looked compared to ADP Rankings:

The above plots show how projections were able to distinguish players who were undervalued/overvalued. The blue label shows how much they overperformed their ADP. For example, in 2016-17, I had Jarvis Landry as undervalued relative to his ADP and in both years he overperformed his ADP. Obviously, there are hits and misses, but for the most part it appears that there are much more hits than misses, which is expected based on the higher correlation. Finally, the plot for 2018:

Conclusion

In this post I examined where there might be edges in fantasy football. I found that ADP is hard to beat, but an analytical approach for WR/TE's allows you to gain an edge compared to ADP, while RBs have had less success with analytical approaches. Some guys the stats like relative to their ADP this year include Tyreek Hill, Brandin Cooks, Jamison Crowder, Nelson Agholor, and others. In my next post I'll show the complete projections, but if you want to you can get the data for the analysis here.

item.title: NFL Betting and Sample Size
item.dc:creator: dlm1223@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
In betting, one thing that people definitely have a misunderstanding of is sample size. I've been getting into NFL betting lately so I wanted to look at how sample size matters when betting on a spread. If you assume you have no edge, you'd expect to win a spread-bet 50% of the time. In other words, this is the null hypothesis and to assume you actually have an edge you'd need a decent sample size of winning. To visualize this in R, I simulate the win rate assuming that you're true edge is 50% i.e. you have no edge. 

  #number of games to simulate
  numGames<-50

  #100,000 different 50-game simulations, sampling from c(0, 1)
  allSamples<-replicate(100000, sum(sample(c(0, 1), size = numGames, replace = T))/numGames) 
  hist(allSamples)

The above plot shows the distribution of outcomes for betting on 50 games with no edge. To do this, I simulate 50 games of betting, and I repeat it 100,000 different times to get a distrubition. I can calculate the probability of getting 58% win-rate for example, just by calculating from the simulations, which is also the same as using pbinom() in R:

sum(allSamples>.58)/length(allSamples)

## [1] 0.10272

1-pbinom(.58*50,50, p=.5 )

## [1] 0.1013194

I got 10% of getting at least a 58% win rate in 50 games with no edge. In other words, if you went 29-21 in 50 games, there is a 10% chance you would have done this just by chance. Or if you took 10 people with no skill, you'd expect one of these people to go at least 29-21.

Finally, I visualize how it looks for different sample sizes.

for(numGames in c(50, 200, 1000)){

  #sample
  allSamples<-replicate(100000, sum(sample(c(0, 1), size = numGames, replace = T))/numGames)

  #plot
  hist(allSamples, main=paste0(numGames, " Games Win Rate"), xlab="Win Rate")
  abline(v=.53,lty=2)
  abline(v=.58,lty=2)
  mtext(paste0("53% Win Rate=", sum(allSamples>.53)/length(allSamples)*100, "% chance; ",
               "58% Win Rate=", sum(allSamples>.58)/length(allSamples)*100, "% chance "
  ))

}

And double check with pbinom()

1-pbinom(50*.53, 50, .5)

## [1] 0.3359055

1-pbinom(200*.53, 200, .5)

## [1] 0.1790015

1-pbinom(1000*.53, 1000, .5)

## [1] 0.02683892


The plots show how your chance of having won just by luck decreases as you get a bigger sample size. All of this isn't that advanced but it's interesting to me to see how sample size is important. If you think you have an edge, it's hard to get the sample size to be sure of it at something like the 5% level, so maybe you just have to go with it at a less certain percent and just manage your bankroll wisely. All of this at least gives some perspective on how win rates can be very influenced by luck.

item.title: NCAAB 2018/19 All-Conference Teams and Underrated Players
item.dc:creator: dlm1223@gmail.com

item.title: Analyzing Pro Football Focus Player Grades
item.dc:creator: dlm1223@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
People site PFF Grades a lot, but I haven't seen a lot of analyses that assess their accuracy. For this analysis, I compare PFF Player Grades, Pro-football-ref's Approximate Value Rating, and also Preseason Madden Ratings. To assess their accuracy, I look at descriptive accuracy and predictive accuracy, using a response variable of whether a player made a Pro.Bowl/All Pro Team for their position.

Descriptive Accuracy

The data I have is taken from Pro-Football-Reference. For every player I have their end-of-year PFF Rating, their end of year Approximate Value (AV) Rating, and their Preseason Madden Rating. In addition, I have the response variable of whether they were selected to the Pro Bowl or an All-Pro team for their position. The data I use is from 2006-present. You can see a preview below:

Player Season Teams PosREF PFF.Grade Madden.Rating AV GamesStart recYDS rushYDS Pro.Bowl
Alvin Kamara 2017 Nor RB 90.5 76 15 3 826 728 1
Dion Lewis 2017 Nwe RB 88.7 82 11 8 214 896 1
Alexander Collins 2017 Bal RB 83.4 NA 9 12 187 973 0
Todd Gurley 2017 Lar RB 83.4 85 19 15 788 1305 1
Kareem Hunt 2017 Kan RB 82.4 75 15 16 455 1327 1
Aaron Jones 2017 Gnb RB 78.8 70 3 4 22 448 0
Cj Anderson 2017 Den RB 78.2 85 7 16 224 1007 0
Jerick Mckinnon 2017 Min RB 77.8 80 9 1 421 570 0
Tarik Cohen 2017 Chi RB 77.5 72 6 4 353 370 0
Lesean Mccoy 2017 Buf RB 75.8 92 11 16 448 1138 1


I can now look at correlations. Which statistic is best correlated to whether a player made it as a pro bowl/all pro? I filter it to only players who started in at least 14 games and only players without any missing values.

PosREF2 Madden.Rating PFF.Grade AV AV.G LastPro.Bowl rushYDS passYDS recYDS n
DB 0.424 0.447 0.739 0.742 0.416 NA NA NA 899
DL 0.459 0.451 0.728 0.730 0.498 NA NA NA 856
LB 0.359 0.465 0.772 0.773 0.414 NA NA NA 688
OL 0.423 0.436 0.623 0.628 0.499 NA NA NA 1264
QB 0.445 0.570 0.576 0.569 0.288 NA 0.443 NA 235
RB 0.307 0.487 0.649 0.640 0.274 0.668 NA NA 170
TE 0.487 0.523 0.686 0.684 0.520 NA NA 0.632 207
WR 0.453 0.619 0.687 0.689 0.313 NA NA 0.672 397

The above table and graph show how Approximate Values is the most correlated to whether a player makes a pro bowl. I believe they might actually use this info when they make the AV Rating, and so this might not be the most fair analysis. It is interesting how PFF Grades aren't so much better than just using a player's preseason Madden Rating.


Predictive Accuracy

Next I look at predictive accuracy. The real judge of a player rating should be how they predict future preformance. I want to see how well all of the stats correlated to them being in the pro bowl next year. I use the same stats, and I also include their next season's Madden Rating, since that is available pre-season. Again, I limit it to players who started in 14 games so that I don't include a player with a high PFF Score who only played in a couple games.

PosREF2 Madden.Rating PFF.Grade AV AV.G Pro.Bowl NextMadden.Rating rushYDS passYDS recYDS n
DB 0.319 0.242 0.380 0.379 0.424 0.388 NA NA NA 740
DL 0.358 0.371 0.407 0.408 0.452 0.432 NA NA NA 703
LB 0.276 0.358 0.397 0.410 0.410 0.396 NA NA NA 575
OL 0.348 0.385 0.366 0.367 0.512 0.444 NA NA NA 1041
QB 0.384 0.381 0.312 0.314 0.255 0.433 NA 0.292 NA 205
RB 0.233 0.218 0.274 0.279 0.263 0.360 0.285 NA NA 147
TE 0.414 0.397 0.502 0.498 0.479 0.480 NA NA 0.455 175
WR 0.329 0.373 0.400 0.404 0.388 0.441 NA NA 0.443 341

Looking at the correlations, you can see the PFF score is not very highly correlated to next year's pro bowl. Preseason Madden Rating is more highly correlated across the board than using their last year's PFF Grade. In other words, at the start of a season, you're better off using Madden Ratings than judging a player with their last year's PFF score. Even simply looking at whether a player made the pro bowl in the previous year is a pretty good variable. PFF Grades still might be useful to include in a model and might add predictive value in addition to other variables, but on their own they are not that useful.
